head.supplied: 7/10/88 ¶ ¶ One of the Cassinias, brought by you, dear Professor Tate, ¶ is what from specimens with young flowers I described as Humea punctulata in fragment. lll, 137. Let it now then under our un...

div.p: Barr Smith Library, University of Adelaide, SA.

One of the Cassinias, brought by you, dear Professor Tate,
Tate attended the first Congress of the Australasian Association for the Advancement of Science, held in Sydney, 28 August-3 September 1888. He may have called on M in Melbourne on his way to Sydney. is what from specimens with young flowers I described as Humea punctulata in fragment. lll, 137. Let it now then under our united authority Cassinia punctulata be called.
M apparently changed his mine about this, since the name Cassinia puctulata was never published.

Could you spare an other fragment of the plant? If you found it in the Murray-Region also, it could still be included into the Addenda of the "Key", which in about a week will be finished as regards msc, and in about 2 weeks as regards printing, and in about 3 weeks as regards stitching.

When I came to look more carefully at the parcel of dried plants, which you saw in one of my work-rooms, I found, that it contained mostly common plants. So it will be better, that I prepare a select lot for you purposely; but give me a little time; Jurors duty at the Exhib.,
Centennial International Exhibition, Melbourne, 1888-9. preparing for the therapeutic section of the Med. Congress,
Intercolonial Medical Congress of Australasia, Melbourne, January 1889. and initiating (this week) the work for the Melb. Meeting of the Austr. Assoc
M was President of the second Congress of the Australasian Association for the Advancement of Science, held in Melbourne in January 1890. press together very heavily just now on me in addition to the daily routine-work
